revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Horst Seehofer |image = 12-07-17-landtagsprojekt-bayern-RalfR-001.jpg |office = [[Federal Ministry of the Interior, Building and Community|Minister of the Interior, Building and Community]] |chancellor = [[Angela Merkel]] |term_start = 14 March 2018 |term_end = |predecessor = [[Thomas de Maizière]] {{small|(Interior)}} |successor = |office1 = [[Leader of the Christian Social Union in Bavaria|Leader of the Christian Social Union]] |term_start1 = 25 October 2008 |term_end1 = |predecessor1 = [[Erwin Huber]] |successor1 = |1blankname1 = {{nowrap|General Secretary}} |1namedata1 = [[Karl-Theodor zu Guttenberg]]
[[Alexander Dobrindt]]
[[Andreas Scheuer]]
[[Markus Blume]] |office2 = [[President of Germany]]
{{small|Acting}} |chancellor2 = [[Angela Merkel]] |term_start2 = 17 February 2012 |term_end2 = 18 March 2012 |predecessor2 = [[Christian Wulff]] |successor2 = [[Joachim Gauck]] |office3 = [[President of the German Bundesrat|President of the Bundesrat]] |term_start3 = 1 November 2011 |term_end3 = 31 October 2012 |predecessor3 = [[Hannelore Kraft]] |successor3 = [[Winfried Kretschmann]] |office4 = [[List of Ministers-President of Bavaria|Minister President of Bavaria]] |deputy4 = [[Martin Zeil]]
[[Ilse Aigner]] |term_start4 = 27 October 2008 |term_end4 = 13 March 2018 |predecessor4 = [[Günther Beckstein]] |successor4 = [[Ilse Aigner]] {{small|(Acting)}} |office5 = [[Federal Ministry of Food and Agriculture (Germany)|Minister of Food, Agriculture and Consumer Protection]] |chancellor5 = [[Angela Merkel]] |term_start5 = 22 November 2005 |term_end5 = 27 October 2008 |predecessor5 = [[Renate Künast]] |successor5 = [[Ilse Aigner]] |office6 = [[Federal Ministry of Health (Germany)|Minister of Health]] |chancellor6 = [[Helmut Kohl]] |term_start6 = 6 May 1992 |term_end6 = 26 October 1998 |predecessor6 = [[Gerda Hasselfeldt]] |successor6 = [[Andrea Fischer]] |office7 = Member of the [[Bundestag]]
for [[Ingolstadt]] |term_start7 = 5 October 1980 |term_end7 = 27 October 2008 |predecessor7 = [[Karl Heinz Gierenstein]] |successor7 = [[Reinhard Brandl]] |office8 = Member of the [[Landtag of Bavaria]]
for Neuburg-Schrobenhausen |term_start8 = 7 October 2013 |term_end8 = 30 April 2018 |predecessor8 = None |successor8 = Matthias Enghuber |birth_name = Horst Lorenz Seehofer |birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=y|1949|7|4}} |birth_place = [[Ingolstadt]], [[West Germany|Germany]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Christian Social Union in Bavaria|Christian Social Union]] |spouse = [[Karin Seehofer]] |children = 4 |website = {{url|horst-seehofer.de|Official website}} |signature = Signature of Horst Seehofer.png }} '''Horst Lorenz Seehofer''' (born 4 July 1949) is a German politician serving as [[Leader of the Christian Social Union in Bavaria|Leader of the Christian Social Union]] (CSU) since 2008 and [[Federal Ministry of the Interior, Building and Community|Minister of the Interior, Building and Community]] since 2018 under Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]]. From 2008 to 2018, he was [[List of Minister-Presidents of Bavaria|Minister President of Bavaria]]; he also served as [[President of the German Bundesrat|President of the Bundesrat]] between 2011 and 2012. First elected to the [[Bundestag]] in [[West German federal election, 1980|1980]], he served as [[Federal Minister for Health and Social Security (Germany)|Federal Minister for Health and Social Security]] from 1992 to 1998 and as [[Federal Ministry of Food, Agriculture and Consumer Protection (Germany)|Federal Minister of Food, Agriculture and Consumer Protection]] in the [[Cabinet Merkel I|cabinet]] of [[Angela Merkel]] from 2005 to 2008. In October 2008 he became Leader of the CSU and the [[List of Minister-Presidents of Bavaria|18th Minister President of Bavaria]]. From 1 November 2011 until 31 October 2012 he served as [[President of the Bundesrat]] and ''ex officio'' deputy to the [[President of Germany]]. Because of that he was [[President of the Bundesrat|Acting President of Germany]] after the resignation of President [[Christian Wulff]] on 17 February 2012 and before the election of [[Joachim Gauck]] as Wulff's successor on 18 March 2012.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aCOKp59WbZE8&refer=germany|title=Germany's Seehofer, Merkel Ally, Elected Bavarian State Premier|publisher=Bloomberg|date=27 October 2008|accessdate=2011-07-09}} A staunch opponent of [[Chancellor of Germany|Chancellor]] [[Angela Merkel]]'s [[Syrian refugee crisis|refugee]] policy,Andrea Thomas (20 November 2015), [https://www.wsj.com/articles/angela-merkel-csus-horst-seehofer-clash-over-german-policy-for-migrants-1448045949 Angela Merkel, CSU’s Horst Seehofer Clash Over German Policy for Migrants] ''[[Wall Street Journal]]''. Seehofer has threatened to file a formal complaint against the Merkel government's refugee policy with Germany's Constitutional CourtMichelle Martin (31 January 2016), [https://www.reuters.com/article/us-germany-russia-idUSKCN0V90XH Bavarian leader defends planned visit to Putin in Moscow] ''[[Reuters]]''. and is a proponent of a federal cap on the number of refugees the German government is to take in.Ruth Bender (14 January 2016), [https://www.wsj.com/articles/bavarian-town-protests-merkels-refugee-policy-with-busload-of-migrants-1452802030 Bavarian Town Protests Merkel’s Refugee Policy With Busload of Migrants] ''[[Wall Street Journal]]''. ==Early life and education== After secondary school, Seehofer started working as civil servant in the local administration in [[Ingolstadt]].Toby Vogel (5 February 2014), [http://www.politico.eu/article/alpha-male/ Horst Seehofer – Alpha male] ''[[Politico Europe|European Voice]]''. ==Political career== ===Federal Minister and Member of the Bundestag (1980–2008)=== Seehofer served as member of the German federal parliament ([[Bundestag]]) from 1980 until 2008. Seehofer was [[Federal Minister for Health and Social Security (Germany)|Federal Minister for Health and Social Security]] from 1992 to 1998 in the [[cabinet of Germany|cabinet]] of [[Chancellor of Germany|Chancellor]] [[Helmut Kohl]]. In 1993, Seehofer ordered that Germany's 117-year-old Federal Health Agency be dissolved following a review of how the government in the 1980s handled the cases of thousands of [[Haemophilia|hemophiliacs]] who were infected through blood contaminated with [[HIV]]. The Health Ministry took over the agency's responsibilities.[https://www.nytimes.com/1993/10/15/world/german-agency-says-it-erred-in-hiv-case.html German Agency Says It Erred in H.I.V. Case] ''[[New York Times]]'', 15 October 1993. Also, Seehofer announced that Germany would contribute to an emergency fund for victims of the scandal.Craig R. Whitney (13 November 1993), [https://www.nytimes.com/1993/11/13/world/germany-to-pay-victims-in-aids-blood-scandal.html Germany to Pay Victims in AIDS Blood Scandal] ''[[New York Times]]''. In the context of the crisis, he came under considerable pressure to resign.Stephen Kinzer (5 November 1993), [https://www.nytimes.com/1993/11/05/world/fear-of-hiv-infected-blood-spreads-past-german-borders.html Fear of H.I.V.-Infected Blood Spreads Past German Borders] ''[[New York Times]]''. [[File:2008-06-01 Angela Merkel und Horst Seehofer 01-045.JPG|thumb|left|Seehofer with Angela Merkel, 2008]] Seehofer became deputy chairman of the [[CDU/CSU]] [[parliamentary group]] of the Bundestag in October 1998, which was led at the time by [[Wolfgang Schäuble]]. He served as Health Minister [[Ulla Schmidt]]'s counterpart in negotiating the cross-party healthcare bill of 2003. Because of his disagreement with CDU leader [[Angela Merkel]] on flat-rate contributions (''Gesundheitsprämie'') to the federal health insuranceBertrand Benoit (17 October 2005), [https://www.ft.com/content/bc00844c-3a61-11da-b0d3-00000e2511c8 Angela Merkel’s cabinet] ''[[Financial Times]]''. he resigned from his post on 22 November 2004 but remained the deputy chairman of the CSU and kept his mandate. After joining the ''Bundestag'' Seehofer kept his mandate as a directly elected delegate (''Direktkandidat'') from his [[Constituency]] [[Ingolstadt (electoral district)|Ingolstadt]]. At the [[German federal election, 2005|2005 federal election]] he received 65.9 percent of the votes in his district. Seehofer was appointed [[Federal Ministry of Food, Agriculture and Consumer Protection|Federal Minister of Food, Agriculture and Consumer Protection]] in the [[Cabinet Merkel I|cabinet]] of Angela Merkel and stayed in office from 2005 to 2008. ===Minister President of Bavaria (2008–2018)=== After his party lost more than 17% of the popular vote in the [[Bavaria state election, 2008|Bavarian state elections of 2008]], incumbent Minister-President [[Günther Beckstein]] and Chairman of the CSU, [[Erwin Huber]], announced their resignations.{{cite web|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2008/09/30/uk-germany-csu-idUKTRE48T1TH20080930|title=Bavaria's CSU leader quits after election blow|publisher=Reuters|date=30 September 2008|accessdate=2011-07-09}}{{cite web| url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2008/10/01/uk-germany-csu-idUKTRE4903TQ20081001|title=Second CSU leader quits, raising risks for Merkel|publisher=Reuters|date=1 October 2008|accessdate=2011-07-09}} Seehofer was quickly proposed as their successor. At a party convention on 25 October he was affirmed as the new Chairman of the CSU with 90% of the votes, and on 27 October he was elected Minister-President by the [[Landtag of Bavaria|Landtag]] with votes from the [[Free Democratic Party (Germany)|Free Democratic Party]], forming the first [[coalition]] government in Bavaria since 1962. During the term 2011–2012, Seehofer served as [[President of the German Bundesrat]]. As such, he acted as Acting [[President of Germany]] between [[Christian Wulff]]'s resignation on 17 February 2012{{cite web|url=http://www.bundesrat.de/cln_235/nn_6898/DE/presse/pm/2012/024-2012.html?__nnn=true|title=Bundesratspräsident nimmt Befugnisse des Bundespräsidenten wahr|publisher=Bundesrat|date=17 February 2012|accessdate=2012-02-17|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130811043315/http://www.bundesrat.de/cln_235/nn_6898/DE/presse/pm/2012/024-2012.html?__nnn=true|archivedate=11 August 2013|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|title=President Wulff resigns|url=http://www.thelocal.de/politics/20120217-40809.html|publisher=[[The Local]]|accessdate=17 February 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/nach-wullf-ruecktritt-staatsoberhaupt-seehofer-1.1287416|title=Staatsoberhaupt Seehofer|language=German|publisher=Süddeutsche Zeitung|date=18 February 2012|accessdate=2012-03-20}}{{cite web|url=https://www.welt.de/regionales/muenchen/article13873734/Horst-Seehofer-ist-kommissarisches-Staatsoberhaupt.html|title=Horst Seehofer ist kommissarisches Staatsoberhaupt|language=German|publisher=Welt Online|date=17 February 2012|accessdate=2012-03-20}}{{cite web|url=http://www.zeit.de/news/2012-02/17/bundespraesident-portraet-seehofer-kommissarisches-staatsoberhaupt-17122211|title=Porträt: Seehofer kommissarisches Staatsoberhaupt|language=German|publisher=Zeit Online|date=17 February 2012|accessdate=2012-03-20}} and the [[German presidential election, 2012|election]] of [[Joachim Gauck]] on 18 March 2012. Under Seehofer's leadership, the State of Bavaria took to the [[Federal Constitutional Court of Germany|Federal Constitutional Court]] in 2012 in order to dispute the legality of Germany's post-World War II system of financial redistribution among the country's 16 states. Bavaria, a beneficiary of the system until 1988, had paid more in 2011 than it got out in the 40 years it was a net recipient.Rainer Buergin (17 July 2012), [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2012-07-17/bavaria-to-challenge-germany-s-postwar-system-of-state-finances Bavaria to Challenge Germany’s Postwar System of State Finances] ''[[Bloomberg Business]]''. The State of [[Hesse]], another per-capita contributor, joined the lawsuit.Joseph de Weck (5 February 2013), [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-02-05/two-richest-german-states-challenge-system-of-paying-for-poor Richest German States Challenge System of Paying for Poor] ''[[Bloomberg Business]]''. Also under Seehofer's leadership, the CSU won an absolute majority in the [[Bavarian state election, 2013|2013 state elections]], heralding strong momentum for the conservative parties in the [[German federal election, 2013|federal elections]] the following week.[http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/bavarian-election-victory-for-conservatives-gives-merkel-a-boost-a-922407.html CSU Triumph: Bavarian Vote Gives Merkel Pre-Election Boost] ''[[Spiegel Online]]'', 16 September 2013. Together with Angela Merkel and [[Sigmar Gabriel]], he later led the negotiations to form a [[coalition government]] on the national level. In late 2013, Seehofer won a record 95.3 percent of the party's votes to continue as chairman.Paul Carrel (30 October 2015), [https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/10/30/us-germany-coalition-idUSKCN0SO1CJ20151030 Horst Seehofer: Merkel ally turned menace-in-chief] ''[[Reuters]]''. In early 2015, under pressure from younger rivals, Seehofer announced he would retire at the next state elections in 2018.Stefan Wagstyl (7 October 2015), [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/9cc055a8-6c24-11e5-aca9-d87542bf8673.html Bavarian ally proves a thorn in Merkel’s side on refugees] ''[[Financial Times]]''. Later that year, when was chosen the fifth time as leader of the CSU, he received 87.2 percent of the vote, some 8 percent down on the result he achieved in 2013.[http://www.dw.com/en/bavarian-premier-seehofer-re-elected-csu-party-leader/a-18866331 Bavarian premier Seehofer re-elected CSU party leader] ''[[Deutsche Welle]]'', 21 November 2015. [[File:Reuven Rivlin visit to Germany, September 2017 (3410).jpg|thumb|Horst Seehofer and Israeli President [[Reuven Rivlin]], 2017]] In August 2016, Seehofer said he may break with party unity and run a separate campaign in the [[German federal election, 2017|2017 national elections]], a move widely seen as an effort to keep pressure on Merkel to shift to a more restrictive refugee policy in the [[European migrant crisis]].Rainer Buergin (1 August 2016), [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-08-01/merkel-s-bavarian-ally-hints-at-snub-of-chancellor-in-2017-vote Merkel’s Bavarian Ally Hints at Snub of Chancellor in 2017 Vote] ''[[Bloomberg News]]''. He also announced to stay on as CSU leader beyond 2018.Joern Poltz and Paul Carrel (24 April 2017), [https://www.reuters.com/article/us-germany-politics/merkel-ally-seehofer-staying-on-for-difficult-german-election-idUSKBN17Q1EF Merkel ally Seehofer staying on for 'difficult' German election] ''[[Reuters]]''. When the CSU's share of the vote in Bavaria fell 10 percentage points compared with 2013, to below 39 per cent, Seehofer faced demands to resign.Guy Chazan (27 September 2017), [https://www.ft.com/content/b1e1493c-a35f-11e7-b797-b61809486fe2 Bavarian party chief faces resignation calls over poll result] ''[[Financial Times]]''. On 4 December 2017, he announced to step down as Minister President and not running as leading candidate in the 2018 state elections;Guy Chazan (4 December 2017), [https://www.ft.com/content/421ba572-d8e6-11e7-a039-c64b1c09b482 Bavarian PM Horst Seehofer steps down in CSU power struggle] ''[[Handelsblatt]]'' instead, he said he would hand over the office to [[Markus Söder]] in the first quarter of 2018.Emily Schultheis (4 December 2017), [https://www.politico.eu/article/horst-seehofer-to-step-down-as-bavarian-state-premier-csu-germany-elections/ Seehofer to quit as Bavarian premier to end power struggle] ''[[Politico Europe]]''. ===Return to federal cabinet (2018–present)=== On 1 March 2018, Seehofer confirmed that he will be in Merkel's cabinet if the SPD party members vote in favour of the coalition.{{cite news|title=CSU's Horst Seehofer confirms he will join Angela Merkel's cabinet|url=http://www.dw.com/en/csus-horst-seehofer-confirms-he-will-join-angela-merkels-cabinet/a-42793190|accessdate=16 March 2018|publisher=Deutsche Welle|date=1 March 2018}} He took over the role of Interior Minister. A policy Seehofer announced is that he has a "master plan for faster asylum procedures, and more consistent deportations."{{cite news|title=Germany's future interior minister Horst Seehofer vows to increase deportations|url=http://www.dw.com/en/germanys-future-interior-minister-horst-seehofer-vows-to-increase-deportations/a-42925097|accessdate=16 March 2018|publisher=Deusche Welle|date=11 March 2018}} He wants a "zero tolerance" policy toward criminals. On 15 March 2018, Seehoher stated that he disagreed with the belief that the Islamic faith is part of German culture.{{cite news|last=Staudenmaier|first=Rebecca|title=German Interior Minister Horst Seehofer: 'Islam doesn't belong to Germany'|url=http://www.dw.com/en/german-interior-minister-horst-seehofer-islam-doesnt-belong-to-germany/a-42999726|accessdate=16 March 2018|publisher=Deusche Welle|date=16 March 2018}} He noted that certain public holidays correspond to certain church holidays. In June 2018, Seehofer backed down from a threat to bypass Chancellor Angela Merkel in a disagreement over immigration policy Until she comes back on July 1 during while she attempts to find a solution at European level. Under Seehofer plan Germany would rejected migrants who have already been deported or have an entry ban and would instruct police to turn away all migrants who have registered elsewhere in the EU.https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/06/germany-interior-minister-merkel-ultimatum-migrants-180618093627915.htmlhttps://www.telegraphindia.com/world/germany-s-interior-minister-horst-seehofer-wants-quick-action-on-migra-dgtl-238561 On 1 July 2018, Seehofer offered to resign after rejecting Chancellor Angela Merkel's EU migration deal.https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/07/merkel-coalition-crisis-seehofer-offers-quit-migration-180702052457364.htmlhttps://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-44674945https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jul/01/merkel-fights-to-save-coalition-from-division-over-migration On 2 July 2018, however, Seehofer and Merkel announced they had settled their differences and agreed to instead accept a compromise of tighter border control.[https://www.wsj.com/articles/merkel-faces-showdown-over-migrant-policy-1530539359 Germany’s Merkel Secures Deal on Migrants, Averts Government Collapse] The Wall Street JournalNadine Schmidt and Judith Vonberg (2 July 2018). "[https://edition.cnn.com/2018/07/02/europe/merkel-seehofer-government-intl/index.html?no-st=1530570558 Germany's Merkel makes deal with interior minister on migration dispute]". [[CNN International| CNN International Edition]]. edition.cnn.com. Retrieved 2018-07-03. As a result of the agreement, Seehofer agreed to not resign.https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-44685727 ==Political positions== [[File:2013-04-11 Horst Seehofer (Landtag) 102.JPG|thumb|Seehofer, seated in the [[Landtag of Bavaria]] in 2013]] ===Immigration=== In 2010, remarks made by Seehofer according to which Turkish and Arab migrants were no longer needed in Germany were strongly criticized by the Turkish community and by Chancellor Angela Merkel's government.Judy Dempsey (11 October 2010), [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/12/world/europe/12iht-germany.html German Politician Makes Anti-Immigrant Remarks] ''[[International Herald Tribune]]''. In 2011, Seehofer took the debate further when he said those who wanted to stay in Germany should be ready to sign up to German values. He proposed a change to the Bavarian Constitution so that the authorities in the state would be under obligation to help with the integration process but that minorities, too, should be prepared to actively support the integration process.Judy Dempsey (9 March 2011), [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/10/world/europe/10iht-germany10.html Merkel Ally Assails Turkey on Human Rights] ''[[International Herald Tribune]]''. In late 2015, Seehofer and the CSU sharply criticized Chancellor Angela Merkel's refugee policy, as the party's home turf of Bavaria was the main entry point for refugees and other migrants arriving in Germany. Under pressure from Seehofer and his allies, Merkel later restricted cash benefits for refugees and added [[Kosovo]], [[Albania]] and [[Montenegro]] to the list of "safe" countries to which migrants can be returned. He repeatedly called on the federal government to set a cap on the number of refugees Germany should be taking in, saying that the country was able to manage only "200,000 applicants [per year] for asylum … at the most."Janosch Delcker (6 January 2016), [http://www.politico.eu/article/merkel-seehofer-play-nice-cdu-csu-trouble-coalition-migration-refugees/ Merkel and Seehofer play nice, but alliance is under strain] ''[[Politico Europe]]''. Seehofer later threatened to file a complaint against the government's refugee policy with Germany's [[Federal Constitutional Court of Germany|Constitutional Court]]. ===Foreign policy=== Seehofer is opposed to [[Turkey]]'s becoming a member of the [[European Union]]. In 2009, he stated that Turkey "as a self-proclaimed representative of the Muslim world, clearly doesn't fit in".Ben Hall and Chris Bryant (9 April 2009), [http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/c46c2286-249f-11de-9a01-00144feabdc0.html France and Germany play politics with accession] ''[[Financial Times]]''. In December 2010 and November 2011, Seehofer was the first Minister-President of Bavaria who visited the neighbouring [[Czech Republic]]; this was considered an important step in the dispute over the expulsion of the [[Sudeten Germans]] after the Second World War. In February 2013, Seehofer received [[Petr Nečas]] as the first Czech Prime Minister for an official visit to Bavaria. In an interview with news magazine ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' in late 2014, Seehofer warned Germany's foreign minister [[Frank-Walter Steinmeier]] and his fellow Social Democrats ([[Social Democratic Party of Germany|SPD]]) against pursuing a more friendly approach towards Russia in the [[Ukraine crisis 2014|Ukrainian crisis]], arguing that "if Mr. Steinmeier is pursuing his own form of diplomacy alongside the chancellor, that would be highly dangerous."Michael Nienaber (22 November 2014), [https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/11/22/ukraine-crisis-germany-russia-idUSL6N0TC0MO20141122#LxlKwHRYYiCpHkuB.97 Merkel ally warns SPD against own diplomacy towards Russia] ''[[Reuters]]''.Stefan Wagstyl and Roula Khalaf (26 November 2014), [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/93e5e066-757a-11e4-b1bf-00144feabdc0.html Merkel offers Russia trade talks olive branch] ''[[Financial Times]]''. He added that, even within his own party, there was already too much friendly sentiment towards Russia that had to be kept in check.Nikolaus Blome, Peter Müller, Christian Neef, Ralf Neukirch and Christoph Schult (25 November 2014), [http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/german-government-shows-faults-in-stance-on-russia-a-1004754.html Relations at Rock Bottom: Cracks Form in Berlin Over Russia Stance] ''[[Der Spiegel]]''. However, in 2015, he held that it would be "[[Realpolitik]]" to try to involve Russia in tackling global crises.Arne Delfs (21 November 2015), [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-11-21/merkel-s-bavarian-ally-plans-putin-visit-in-bid-for-global-stage Merkel's Bavarian Ally Plans Putin Visit in Bid for Global Stage] ''[[Bloomberg Business]]''. In early 2016, his joint visit with [[Edmund Stoiber]] to Moscow for talks with Russian President [[Vladimir Putin]] was met by harsh criticism, even from CDU politicians. By early 2017, Seehofer reiterated his calls to lift the [[International sanctions during the Ukrainian crisis|EU sanctions]] against Russia.Andrea Shalal (28 January 2017), [https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ukraine-crisis-russia-germany-idUSKBN15D005 Merkel's Bavarian ally calls for quick end to Russian sanctions] ''[[Reuters]]''. In September 2018, a few days after [[2018 Chemnitz protests|Chemnitz protests against migrants and refugees]], Seehofer criticized the debate on migration again saying it is "the mother of all political problems" in Germany.{{Cite web|url=https://www.dw.com/en/migration-mother-of-all-political-problems-says-german-interior-minister-horst-seehofer/a-45378092|title=Migration 'mother of all political problems,' says German Interior Minister Horst Seehofer {{!}} DW {{!}} 06.09.2018|last=(www.dw.com)|first=Deutsche Welle|website=DW.COM|language=en|access-date=2018-09-06}} ===European integration=== In 2012, Seehofer demanded that the [[Basic Law for the Federal Republic of Germany|German constitution]] be changed to permit [[referendum]]s on decisions to deepen [[European integration]] and transfer powers to [[Institutions of the European Union|European institutions]]. That same year, he criticized [[International Monetary Fund]] managing director [[Christine Lagarde]]'s proposal for measures that would result in a mutualization of [[Eurozone]] debt, arguing that shared liability for [[sovereign debt]] and a banking union would remove pressure from governments to carry out economic policy changes.Rainer Buergin (29 June 2012), [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2012-06-29/lagarde-wrong-to-urge-mutualized-debt-germany-s-seehofer-says Lagarde Wrong to Urge Mutualized Debt, Germany’s Seehofer Says] ''[[Bloomberg Business]]''. In 2013, Seehofer made [[Peter Gauweiler]] a deputy leader of the CSU in a bid to court the party's euro critics; however, Gauweiler quit after two years in protest against the extension of [[Greece]]'s aid program.Rainer Buergin and Patrick Donahue (31 March 2015), [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-03-31/euro-critic-quits-merkel-s-german-coalition-in-protest German Euro Critic Quits Merkel Caucus in Greece Protest] ''[[Bloomberg Business]]''. ==Other activities== ===Corporate boards=== * [[KfW]], Ex-Officio Member of the Supervisory Board (2005–2008)[https://www.kfw.de/Download-Center/Finanzpublikationen/PDF-Dokumente-Berichte-etc./1_Gesch%C3%A4ftsberichte/Gesch%C3%A4ftsbericht_2005_D.pdf 2005 Annual Report] [[KfW]]. * [[Landwirtschaftliche Rentenbank]], Deputy Chairman of the Supervisory Board (−2008) * Donau-Wasserkraft AG (DWK), Member of the Supervisory Board (1998–2005) ===Non-profits=== * German Forum for Crime Prevention (DFK), Ex-Officio Member of the Board of Trustees (since 2018)[http://www.kriminalpraevention.de/kuratorium.html Board of Trustees] German Forum for Crime Prevention (DFK). * [[Deutsches Museum]], Member of the Board of Trustees * Committee for the preparation of the Reformation anniversary 2017, Member of the Board of Trustees * [[Hanns Seidel Foundation]], Member of the Board * Sudetendeutsche Stiftung, Member of the Board of Trustees * Bayerische Landesstiftung, ''ex-officio'' Member of the Board of Trustees (2008–2018) * Bavarian Research Foundation, ''ex-officio'' Member of the Board of Trustees (2008–2018) * German Energy Agency (DENA), Member of the Supervisory Board (−2008) * [[ZDF]], Member of the board of directors (2010–2014) ==Recognition== ===Orders=== * [[File:GER Bundesverdienstkreuz 6 GrVK Stern Band.svg|60px]] [[Grand Cross]] of the [[Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany]] (1996) * [[File:DE-BY Der Bayerische Verdienstorden BAR.png|60px]] [[Bavarian Order of Merit]] (2008) * [[File:POR Ordem do Merito Gra-Cruz BAR.svg|60px]] [[Grand Cross]] of the [[Order of Merit (Portugal)|Order of Merit of Portugal]] (2009) * [[File:ITA OSI 2011 GC BAR.svg|60px]] [[Grand Cross|Knight Grand Cross]] of the [[Order of the Star of Italy]] (2014)[https://www.welt.de/regionales/niedersachsen/article136298485/Weil-erhaelt-Orden-Stern-von-Italien.html Weil erhält Orden "Stern von Italien"] ''[[Die Welt]]'', 12 January 2015.[http://www.stk.niedersachsen.de/aktuelles/presseinformationen/ministerpraesident-weil-erhaelt-hohen-orden-der-italienischen-republik-130517.html Ministerpräsident Weil erhält hohen Orden der Italienischen Republik] State Chancellery of Lower Saxony, press release of 12 January 2015. ===Honorary doctorates=== * Honorary doctorate of the [[National University of Life and Environmental Sciences of Ukraine|National Agricultural University of Ukraine]] (2008)Marc Hujer (20 February 2014), [http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/profile-of-ukraine-opposition-leader-vitali-klitschko-a-954182.html Family Affair: The Klitschko Brothers' Most Important Fight] ''[[Der Spiegel]]''. * Honorary doctorate of the [[Lucian Blaga University of Sibiu]] (2010)[http://www.merkur.de/politik/seehofer-wird-ehrendoktor-siebenbuergen-782134.html Seehofer wird Ehrendoktor in Siebenbürgen] ''[[Münchner Merkur]]''. * Honorary doctorate of [[Qingdao University]] (2010)[http://www.abendzeitung-muenchen.de/inhalt.politik-seehofer-ist-jetzt-ein-chinesischer-professor.082392b9-4eea-4140-a765-26a7b569edb0.html Seehofer ist jetzt ein chinesischer Professor] ''[[Abendzeitung]]'', 29 April 2010. ==Personal life== Seehofer is married to [[Karin Seehofer]] and resides in the Ingolstadt district of [[Gerolfing]]. A father of three, Seehofer failed in a 2007 bid for the CSU leadership when it emerged that he had a daughter born out of wedlock, from an extramarital affair with a much younger staffer of the German Bundestag. After a period of indecision, he opted to return to his wife. In 2002, Seehofer survived a serious [[myocarditis]]. His health again became a subject of public debate when he collapsed during a speech at a party event in early 2015.Joseph Nasr (19 January 2016), [http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-germany-politics-seehofer-idUKKCN0UX212 Leader of Merkel's Bavarian allies collapses at party event] ''[[Reuters]]''. ==References== {{Reflist|3}} ==External links== {{Commonscat}} * {{official website|http://www.horst-seehofer.de/ }} * [https://www.webcitation.org/67ltVJy5M?url=http://www.bayern.de/Horst-Seehofer-.1853.htm Official Bavarian government website] Biography of Horst Seehofer {{de icon}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Gerda Hasselfeldt]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Federal Ministry of Health (Germany)|Minister of Health]]|years=1992–1998}} {{s-aft|after=[[Andrea Fischer]]}} |- {{s-bef|before=[[Renate Künast]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Federal Ministry of Food and Agriculture (Germany)|Minister of Food, Agriculture and Consumer Protection]]|years=2005–2008}} {{s-aft|after=[[Ilse Aigner]]}} |- {{s-bef|before=[[Günther Beckstein]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[List of Ministers-President of Bavaria|Minister President of Bavaria]]|years=2008–2018}} {{s-aft|after=[[Ilse Aigner]]
{{small|Acting}}}} |- {{s-bef|before=[[Hannelore Kraft]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[President of the German Bundesrat|President of the Bundesrat]]|years=2011–2012}} {{s-aft|after=[[Winfried Kretschmann]]}} |- {{s-bef|before=[[Christian Wulff]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[President of Germany]]
{{small|Acting}}|years=2012}} {{s-aft|after=[[Joachim Gauck]]}} |- {{s-bef|before=[[Thomas de Maizière]]|as=Minister of the Interior}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Federal Ministry of the Interior, Building and Community|Minister of the Interior, Building and Community]]|years=2018–present}} {{s-inc}} |- {{s-ppo}} {{s-bef|before=[[Erwin Huber]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Leader of the [[Christian Social Union in Bavaria|Christian Social Union]]|years=2008–present}} {{s-inc}} {{s-end}} {{Cabinet Merkel I}} {{Cabinet Merkel IV}} {{Interior Ministers of Germany}} {{Ministers-President of Bavaria}} {{German presidents}} {{CSUHeads}} {{G8-Interior}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Seehofer, Horst}} [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:21st-century German politicians]] [[Category:Acting Presidents of Germany]] [[Category:Agriculture ministers of Germany]] [[Category:Christian Social Union in Bavaria politicians]] [[Category:German Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Government ministers of Germany]] [[Category:Health ministers of Germany]] [[Category:Interior ministers of Germany]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the Bundestag for Bavaria]] [[Category:Members of the Landtag of Bavaria]] [[Category:Ministers-President of Bavaria]] [[Category:People from Ingolstadt]] [[Category:Recipients of the Bavarian Order of Merit]] [[Category:Commanders Crosses of the Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany]]

page.title: List of inventors killed by their own inventions

revision.comment: Alter: isbn, title. Add: year, issue, website, date, isbn, author pars. 1-2. Removed parameters. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[User:Anas1712|Anas1712]]
revision.text:
{{pp-semi-indef}} {{pp-move-indef}} [[File:Flying tailor.png|thumb|[[Franz Reichelt]] (d. 1912) attempted to use this contraption as a parachute. Reichelt died after he jumped off the [[Eiffel Tower]] wearing his invention, which failed to operate as expected.]]This is a list of [[inventor]]s whose deaths were in some manner caused by or related to a product, process, procedure, or other innovation that they invented or designed. <!-- Note that citations are provided in the articles linked to. -->
==Direct casualties==
===Automotive=== *[[Sylvester H. Roper]], inventor of the eponymous [[Roper steam velocipede|steam-powered bicycle]], died of a heart attack or subsequent crash during a public speed trial in 1896. It is unknown whether the crash caused the heart attack or the heart attack caused the crash.<ref>{{Citation |newspaper=[[Boston Daily Globe]] |date= 2 June 1896 |pages= 1 |title= Died in the Saddle }}</ref> *[[William Nelson (inventor)|William Nelson]] (c. 1879−1903), a [[General Electric]] employee, invented a new way to [[Motorized bicycle|motorize bicycles]]. He then fell off his prototype bike during a test run.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F02E6DE1039E333A25757C0A9669D946297D6CF|title=KILLED BY OWN INVENTION; While Trying Motor Bicycle He Had Made, Schenectady Man Meets Death — Article Preview|date=4 October 1903|publisher=[[New York Times]]|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> *[[Francis Edgar Stanley]] (1849–1918) was killed while driving a [[Stanley Steamer]] automobile. He drove his car into a woodpile while attempting to avoid farm wagons travelling side by side on the road.<ref>{{cite book |url=//books.google.com/books?id=LTYhAQAAMAAJ |agency= Maine League of Historical Societies and Museums |editor=Doris A. Isaacson |title=Maine: A Guide "Down East"|edition=second |year=1970 |publisher=Courier-Gazette, Inc. |location=Rockland, Maine | page = 386}} ([https://archive.org/details/maineguidedownea00federich First edition]).</ref> *[[Fred Duesenberg]] (1876–1932) was killed in a high-speed road accident in a [[Duesenberg]] automobile.<ref>{{cite news|title=F. S. Duesenberg Dies of Auto Injury|date=27 July 1932|publisher=[[New York Times]]|pages=17}}</ref>
===Aviation=== * [[Ismail ibn Hammad al-Jawhari]] (died c. 1003–1010), a Kazakh [[Turkic peoples|Turkic]] scholar from [[Otrar|Farab]], attempted to fly using two wooden wings and a rope. He leapt from the roof of a mosque in [[Nishapur]] and fell to his death.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jreLHQctCxAC&pg=PA37|title=google.com Piero Boitani, ''Winged words: flight in poetry and history''. University of Chicago Press, 2007. p. 38|publisher=|accessdate=22 November 2014|isbn=9780226065618|last1=Boitani|first1=Piero|last2=Boitani|first2=Professor of Comparative Literature Piero|date=2007-05-15}}</ref> * [[Jean-François Pilâtre de Rozier]] was the first known fatality in an [[air crash]] when his [[Rozière balloon]] crashed on 15 June 1785 while he and Pierre Romain attempted to cross the [[English Channel]]. * [[Otto Lilienthal]] (1848–1896) died the day after crashing one of his [[hang glider]]s.<ref>[http://www.lilienthal-museum.de/olma/ebiog.htm Biography of Otto Lilienthal] Lilienthal Museum</ref> * [[Franz Reichelt]] (1879–1912), a [[tailor]], fell to his death off the first deck of the [[Eiffel Tower]] while testing his invention, the coat [[parachute]]. It was his first attempt with the parachute, and he had told the authorities he would first test it with a [[Mannequin|dummy]].<ref>[http://www.darwinawards.com/personal/personal2003-02.html 2003 Personal Accounts] Darwin Awards</ref> * [[Aurel Vlaicu]] (1882–1913) died when his self-constructed airplane,<ref>[http://v3.espacenet.com/textdoc?IDX=GB191026658&CY=ep&LG=en&DB=EPODOC Great Britain Patent GB191026658]</ref> ''Vlaicu II'', failed during an attempt to cross the [[Carpathian Mountains]] by air.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.earlyaviators.com/evlaicu.htm|title=Aurel Vlaicu at www.earlyaviators.com|author=Ralph S. Cooper, D.V.M.|publisher=|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> * [[Henry Smolinski]] (died 1973) was killed during a test flight of the [[AVE Mizar]], a [[Flying car (aircraft)|flying car]] based on the [[Ford Pinto]] and the sole product of the company he founded.<ref>{{cite book|title=From Fail to Win, Learning from Bad Ideas: Transportation|author=Morris, Neil|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EoExSw2QMXQC&pg=PA10&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=false|year=2010|isbn=978-1-4109-3911-1}}</ref> * [[Michael Dacre]] (died 2009, age 53) died after testing his [[AVCEN Jetpod|flying taxi device]] designed to permit fast, affordable travel between regional cities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23733014-details/British+inventor+dies+in+crash+on+test+flight+of+his+flying+taxi/article.do|title=British inventor dies in crash on test flight of his flying taxi|website=The Evening Standard|accessdate=22 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090820215815/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23733014-details/British+inventor+dies+in+crash+on+test+flight+of+his+flying+taxi/article.do|archivedate=20 August 2009|df=}}</ref>
===Chemistry=== * [[Andrei Zheleznyakov]], a Soviet scientist, was developing chemical weapons in 1987 when a hood malfunction exposed him to traces of the nerve agent Novichok-5. He spent weeks in a coma, months unable to walk, and years of failing health before dying from its effects in 1992/3.<ref> {{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/mar/22/andrei-zheleznyakov-soviet-scientist-poisoned-novichok|title='It's got me': the lonely death of the Soviet scientist poisoned by novichok|publisher= The Guardian|accessdate=27 March 2018}} </ref>
===Industrial=== * [[William Bullock (inventor)|William Bullock]] (1813–1867) invented the web [[rotary printing press]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/patents/about?id=QHMAAAAAEBAJ&dq=William+Bullock|title=United States Patent 61996|publisher=|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/patents?id=wDxRAAAAEBAJ&pg=PP1&dq=William+Bullock|title=United States Patent 100,367|publisher=|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> Several years after its invention, his foot was crushed during the installation of a new machine in [[Philadelphia]]. The crushed foot developed [[gangrene]] and Bullock died during the [[amputation]].<ref name=discovery/>
===Maritime=== [[File:Hunley-2.jpg|right|thumb|Hunley Submarine]] * [[Henry Winstanley]] (1644–1703) built the [[Eddystone_Lighthouse#Winstanley's_lighthouse|first lighthouse on the Eddystone Rocks]] in Devon, England between 1696 and 1698. During the [[Great Storm of 1703]] the lighthouse was completely destroyed with Winstanley and five other men inside. No trace of them was found.<ref name=edthis>{{cite web|title=Eddystone Lighthouse History |url=http://www.eddystoneeel.com/LIGHTHOUSE%20HISTORY.htm |publisher=Eddystone Tatler Ltd |accessdate=7 September 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060502095435/http://www.eddystoneeel.com/LIGHTHOUSE%20HISTORY.htm |archivedate=2 May 2006 }}</ref> * [[Horace Lawson Hunley]] (died 1863, age 40), [[Confederate States of America|Confederate]] marine engineer and inventor of the first combat [[submarine]], [[H. L. Hunley (submarine)|''Hunley'']], died during a trial of his vessel. During a routine test of the submarine, which had already suffered one accident, Hunley took command. After failing to resurface, Hunley and the seven other crew members drowned.<ref name=discovery>{{cite web |url=http://news.discovery.com/human/inventors-killed-by-invention.html |title=Inventors killed by their own inventions |accessdate=2010-10-30 |quote= |publisher=[[Discovery News]] }}</ref> The navy salvaged the submarine and put it back into use.
===Medical=== * [[Alexander Bogdanov]] (22 August 1873 – 7 April 1928) was a Russian physician, philosopher, science fiction writer and revolutionary of Belarusian ethnicity who experimented with blood transfusion, attempting to achieve eternal youth or at least partial rejuvenation. He died after he took the blood of a student suffering from malaria and tuberculosis, who may have also been the wrong blood type.<ref>{{cite journal|title = Transfusion Medical Reviews|year = 2007|pages= 337–340}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal| title= Alexander Bogdanov: the forgotten pioneer of blood transfusion| pmid=17900494 | doi=10.1016/j.tmrv.2007.05.008 | volume=21| issue=4 | journal=Transfus Med Rev| pages=337–40| author=Huestis DW| year=2007 }}</ref> * [[Thomas Midgley, Jr.]] (1889–1944) was an American engineer and chemist who contracted [[polio]] at age 51, leaving him severely disabled. He devised an elaborate system of ropes and pulleys to help others lift him from bed. He became accidentally entangled in the ropes and died of strangulation at the age of 55. However, he is better known for two of his other inventions: the [[tetraethyl lead]] (TEL) additive to [[gasoline]], and [[chlorofluorocarbon]]s (CFCs).<ref>[[Bill Bryson|Bryson, Bill]]. ''[[A Short History of Nearly Everything]]''. (2003) Broadway Books, USA. {{ISBN|0-385-66004-9}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.damninteresting.com/?p=932|title=The Ethyl-Poisoned Earth|date=2007-12-08|work=Damn Interesting|author=Alan Bellows}}</ref><ref>"[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,801605,00.html Milestones, Nov. 13, 1944]" ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', November 13, 1944</ref>
===Physics=== * [[Sabin Arnold von Sochocky]] invented the first radium-based [[Luminous_paint#Radioluminescent_paint|luminescent paint]], but eventually died, in 1928, of aplastic anemia resulting from his exposure to the radioactive material.<ref name="Sochocky">{{cite news|title=Radium paint takes its inventor's life; Dr. Sabin A. von Sochocky Ill a Long Time, Poisoned by Watch Dial Luminant. 13 Blood Transfusions. Death Due to Aplastic Anemia-- Women Workers Who Were Stricken Sued Company| work=[[The New York Times]]| date=15 November 1928}}</ref> * [[Marie Curie]] (1867–1934) invented the process to isolate radium after co-discovering the radioactive elements [[radium]] and [[polonium]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aip.org/history/curie/resbr2.htm|title=American Institute of Physics Biography of Marie Curie|publisher=|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> She died of [[aplastic anemia]] as a result of prolonged exposure to [[ionizing radiation]] emanating from her research materials. The dangers of radiation were not well understood at the time.<ref name="discovery" /><ref>[http://www.aip.org/history/curie/radinst3.htm American Institute of Physics Biography of Marie Curie]</ref>
===Publicity and entertainment===
* [[Karel Soucek]] (1947–1985) was a Canadian professional stuntman who developed a shock-absorbent barrel. He died following a demonstration involving the barrel being dropped from the roof of the [[Houston Astrodome]]. He was fatally wounded when his barrel hit the rim of the water tank meant to cushion his fall.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Los Angeles Times]]|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1985-01-21/news/mn-14186_1_water-tank|title=35,000 Watch as Barrel Misses Water Tank : 180-Ft. Drop Ends in Stunt Man's Death|date= 21 January 1985|author=[[Associated Press]]|accessdate=18 August 2012}}</ref>
===Railway=== * [[Valerian Abakovsky]] (1895–1921) constructed the [[Aerowagon]], an experimental high-speed [[railcar]] fitted with an [[aircraft engine]] and propeller traction; it was intended to carry [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] officials. On 24 July 1921, a group led by [[Fyodor Sergeyev]] took the Aerowagon from [[Moscow]] to the [[Tula, Russia|Tula]] collieries to test it, with Abakovsky also on board. They successfully arrived in Tula, but on the return route to Moscow the Aerowagon derailed at high speed, killing 6 of the 22 on board, including Abakovsky (at the age of 25).<ref>Alexey Abramov / Алексей Абрамов By the Kremlin Wall / У кремлёвской стены Moscow / М., Politizdat / Политиздат 1978 pp./стр. 399 {{ru icon}}</ref>
===Rocketry=== * [[Max Valier]] (1895–1930) invented liquid-fuelled rocket engines as a member of the 1920s German rocketeering society ''[[Verein für Raumschiffahrt]]''. On 17 May 1930, an alcohol-fuelled engine exploded on his test bench in Berlin, killing him instantly.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aiaa.org/content.cfm?pageid=427|title=American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics|publisher=|accessdate=22 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111226141614/http://www.aiaa.org/content.cfm?pageid=427|archivedate=26 December 2011|df=}}</ref>
==Popular myths and related stories== [[File:Pierre Woeiriot Phalaris.jpg|thumb|right|Perillos being pushed into his [[brazen bull]]]] * [[Perillos of Athens]] (circa 550 BCE), according to legend, was the first to be roasted in the [[brazen bull]] he made for [[Phalaris]] of Sicily for executing criminals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.perillos.com/brazenbull.html|title=Perillos of the Brazen Bull|accessdate=25 July 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121216121012/http://www.perillos.com/brazenbull.html|archivedate=16 December 2012|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.medievality.com/brazen-bull.html|title=The Brazen Bull|accessdate=1 October 2011}}</ref> * [[Li Si]] (208 BCE), Prime Minister during the [[Qin dynasty]], was executed by [[the Five Pains]] method which some sources claim he had devised.<ref>Guisso, R. W. L., ''The first emperor of China'', New York : Birch Lane Press, 1989. {{ISBN|1-55972-016-6}}. Cf. [https://books.google.com/books?id=2eg-AQAAIAAJ&q=li+si+five+tortures&dq=li+si+five+tortures&hl=en&ei=zS-ATbXWMYiZ0QGAlYiOCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAA p.37]</ref><ref>Fu, Zhengyuan, [https://books.google.com/books?id=uGZIziWmlmsC&printsec=frontcover ''Autocratic tradition and Chinese politics''], Cambridge University Press, 1993. Cf. [https://books.google.com/books?id=uGZIziWmlmsC&pg=PA126&dq=li+si+five+tortures&hl=en&ei=sj-ATZWgBIbG0QGV85yBCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAzgK#v=onepage&q&f=false p.126]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldwideschool.org/library/books/hst/asian/TheCivilizationofChina/chap2.html|title=The Civilization of China, Chapter II: Law and Government|accessdate=11 August 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150811163902/http://www.worldwideschool.org/library/books/hst/asian/TheCivilizationofChina/chap2.html|archivedate=11 August 2015|df=}}</ref>{{Failed verification|date=October 2016}} However the history of the Five Pains is traced further back in time than Li Si. * [[Wan Hu]], a possibly-apocryphal<ref name="Williamson">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=npI5NsFG8ngC&pg=PA4|title=Spacecraft Technology: The Early Years|publisher=IET|year=2006|author=Williamson, Mark|isbn=9780863415531}}</ref> 16th-century Chinese official, is said to have attempted to launch himself into outer space in a chair to which 47 rockets were attached. The rockets exploded, and it is said that neither he nor the chair were ever seen again.
==See also== {{portal|Death}} *[[Darwin Awards]] *[[List of entertainers who died during a performance]] *[[List of unusual deaths]] *[[Hoist with his own petard]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== * {{cite book |author=E. Cobham Brewer |authorlink=Ebenezer Cobham Brewer |title=Dictionary of Phrase and Fable |year=1898 |chapter=Inventors Punished by their own inventions |url=http://www.bartleby.com/81/8916.html |publisher=Bartleby |pages=657–658}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080209181501/http://world.std.com/~jlr/doom/doom_eng.htm John Redford's "Doomed Engineers" page]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Inventors Killed By Their Own Inventions}} [[Category:Death-related lists]] [[Category:Lists of inventors|Killed]] [[Category:Inventors killed by own invention]]

page.title: List of least carbon efficient power stations

revision.text:
This is a '''list of least carbon efficient power stations''' in selected countries. Lists were created by the [[WWF (conservation organization)|WWF]] and lists the most polluting [[power station]]s in terms of the level of [[carbon dioxide]] produced per unit of electricity generated. In 2005 WWF created list of power stations from 30 industrialised countries, also list for [[European Union|EU]],[http://assets.panda.org/downloads/dirty30rankingfinal260905.pdf Dirty Thirty – Europe’s worst climate polluting power stations] in 2007 WWF published updated EU list. In 2009 [[European Commission]] list with absolute emissions only, also in 2014 [[Climate Action Network]] Europe, WWF, [[European Environmental Bureau]], [[Health and Environment Alliance]] and [[Climate Alliance Germany]]. == 30 industrialised countries list from 2005 report == [http://www.wwf.org.au/News_and_information/News_room/View_news/223 WWF Australia: Hazelwood tops international list of dirty power stations], Dated: 13 Jul 2005 {|class="wikitable sortable" ! {{CO2}} intensity
(kg/kWh) ! Power station ! '''Master of Medicine''' ('''MMed''') is a postgraduate academic degree awarded by [[medical school]]s to physicians following a period of instruction and examination. The degree is awarded by both surgical and medical subspecialties and usually includes a [[dissertation]] component involving original research. The degree may complement an existing [[fellowship (medicine)|fellowship]] in the chosen specialty or be the sole qualification necessary for registration as a specialist.
The following universities in the following countries are known to award MMed degrees, in the following subjects, as of May 2009:
==Australia==
===University of Queensland=== * MMed in [[General Practice]] * MMed in Primary Care Skin Cancer Medicine
===University of Sydney=== * MMed in [[Ophthalmology]]<ref>http://sydney.edu.au/courses/master-of-medicine-ophthalmic-science</ref> * MMed in [[Sleep Medicine]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sleep.med.usyd.edu.au/masters.htm|title=About The MMed Sleep Medicine|author=|date=|website=usyd.edu.au|accessdate=7 April 2018}}</ref> * MMed in [http://sydney.edu.au/courses/master-of-medicine-critical-care-medicine Critical Care Medicine]
===University of Monash=== * MMed in [[Perioperative Medicine]] <ref>{{cite web|url=https://master.periopmedicine.org.au|title=Monash University - Master of Medicine|author=|date=|website=master.periopmedicine.org.au|accessdate=7 April 2018}}</ref>
==Fiji== * MMed
==Guyana==
===Texila American University=== The following MMed courses are available at [[Texila American University]]:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tauedu.org/master-of-medicine-programs.html|title=Texila American University - International Medical & Educational Group|first=Texila American|last=University|date=|website=www.tauedu.org|accessdate=7 April 2018}}</ref>
* [[MMed]] in [[Pediatrics]] * [[MMed]] in [[Psychiatry]] * [[MMed]] in [[Pathology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Surgery]] * [[MMed]] in [[Anesthesia]] * [[MMed]] in [[Ear]] [[Human nose|Nose]] and [[Throat]] [[Surgery]] * [[MMed]] in [[Radiology|Diagnostic Radiology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Obstetrics and Gynecology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Immunology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Internal Medicine]] * [[MMed]] in [[Neurology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Dermatology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Emergency Medicine]] * [[MMed]] in [[Ophthalmology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Orthopaedics]] * [[MMed]] in [[Forensic Medicine]] * [[MMed]] in [[Human Anatomy]] & [[Embryology|Histo-Embryology]]
==Kenya==
===University of Nairobi=== Various MMed courses are available at [[University of Nairobi]]:<ref>[http://med-school.uonbi.ac.ke/admissions_degrees_display/graduate=Masters MMed Programs at University of Nairobi]</ref>
== Malaysia ==
=== Universiti of Malaya === * [[MMed]] in [[Clinical pathology|Clinical Pathology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Medical physics|Medical Physics]] * [[MMed]] in [[Internal Medicine]] * [[MMed]] in [[Emergency medicine|Emergency Medicine]] * [[MMed]] in [[Clinical oncology|Clinical Oncology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Anesthesiologist|Anaesthesiology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Medicine|Medical Science]] * [[MMed]] in [[Nursing|Nursing Science]] * [[MMed]] in [[Obstetrics & Gynaecology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Pediatrics|Paediatrics]] * [[MMed]] in [[Pediatric surgery|Paediatrics Surgery]] * [[MMed]] in [[Otorhinolaryngology]]
=== Universiti Sains Malaysia ===
==== Medical Based Programs ==== * [[MMed]] in [[Anesthesia|Anaesthesiology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Emergency medicine|Emergency Medicine]] * [[MMed]] in [[Family medicine|Family Medicine]] * [[MMed]] in [[Internal medicine|Internal Medicine]] * [[MMed]] in [[Pediatrics|Paediatrics]] * [[MMed]] in [[Psychiatry]] * [[MMed]] in [[Radiology]]
==== Surgical Based Programs ==== * [[MMed]] in [[Obstetrics and gynaecology|Obstetrics & Gynaecology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Ophthalmology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Orthopedic surgery|Orthopaedics]] * [[MMed]] in [[Otorhinolaryngology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Surgery]] * [[MMed]] in [[Neurosurgery]] * [[MMed]] in [[Plastic surgery|Plastic Surgery]]
==Singapore== The Master of Medicine (MMed) is conferred by the [[National University of Singapore]] (NUS) Division of Graduate Medical Studies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.med.nus.edu.sg/dgms/|title=Graduate Medical Studies At NUS|author=|date=|website=nus.edu.sg|accessdate=7 April 2018}}</ref> *[[MMed]] in [[Internal Medicine]] *[[MMed]] in [[Surgery]] (may be taken jointly with the [[Membership of the Royal College of Surgeons|MRCS]] examinations)<ref>{{citeweb|title=Graduate Programmes — Master of Medicine (MMed) Exams: Surgery|url=http://medicine.nus.edu.sg/dgms/our-programmes/master-of-medicine/surgery.shtml|publisher=[[Yong Loo Lin School of Medicine]]}}</ref> *[[MMed]] in [[Pediatrics]] *[[MMed]] in [[Obstetrics & Gynaecology]] *[[MMed]] in [[Occupational Medicine]] *[[MMed]] in [[Public Health]] *[[MMed]] in [[Psychiatry]] *[[MMed]] in [[Family Medicine]] *[[MMed]] in [[Radiology|Diagnostic Radiology]] *[[MMed]] in [[Orthopaedic Surgery]] *[[MMed]] in [[Otorhinolaryngology]] *[[MMed]] in [[Emergency Medicine]]
==South Africa==
===University of Cape Town=== The following MMed courses are available at the [[University of Cape Town]]<ref>[http://www.uct.ac.za/ MMed Programs at the University of Cape Town]</ref> * [[MMed]] in [[Occupational Medicine]] * [[MMed]] in [[Public Health]] * [[MMed]] in [[Anesthesia]] * [[MMed]] in [[Anatomical Pathology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Haematology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Internal Medicine]] * [[MMed]] in [[Microbiology]] and [[Immunology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Obstetrics and Gynecology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Ophthalmology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Orthopedics]] * [[MMed]] in [[Otorhinolaryngology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Pediatrics]] * [[MMed]] in [[Psychiatry]] * [[MMed]] in [[Radiology]] *[[MMed]] in [[Radiation Oncology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Surgery]]
===University of Pretoria=== The following MMed courses are available at the [[University of Pretoria]]<ref>[http://programmes.up.ac.za/index.php?Faculty=F4&mod=postgrad&StudyLevel=3 Health Sciences Retrieved 21 March 2011]</ref> * [[MMed]] in [[Anaesthesiology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Dermatology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Emergency Medicine]] * [[MMed]] in [[Family Medicine]] * [[MMed]] in [[Geriatrics]] * [[MMed]] in [[Internal Medicine]] * [[MMed]] in [[Oncology|Medical Oncology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Neurology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Neurosurgery]] * [[MMed]] in [[Nuclear Medicine]] * [[MMed]] in [[Obstetrics and Gynaecology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Ophthalmology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Orthopaedics]] * [[MMed]] in [[Otorhinolaryngology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Paediatrics]] * [[MMed]] in [[Anatomical Pathology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Pathology|Chemical Pathology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Clinical Pathology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Forensic Pathology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Haematology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Medical Microbiology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Virology|Medical Virology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Plastic Surgery]] * [[MMed]] in [[Psychiatry]] * [[MMed]] in [[Public Health]] * [[MMed]] in [[Oncology|Radiation Oncology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Radiology|Diagnostic Radiology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Surgery]] * [[MMed]] in [[Surgery|Paediatric Surgery]] * [[MMed]] in [[Thoracic Surgery]] * [[MMed]] in [[Urology]] * [[MMed|MMilMed]] - [[Military medicine|Master of Military Medicine]]
==Taiwan, Republic of China==
===Fu Jen Catholic University=== * [[MMed]] in [[Clinical Psychology]]
==Tanzania==
===Muhimbili University=== The following MMed courses are available at [[Muhimbili University]]:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.muchs.ac.tz/medicine/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=14&Itemid=27|title=MMed Courses at Muhimbili University|author=|date=|website=muchs.ac.tz|accessdate=7 April 2018}}</ref>
* [[MMed]] in [[Anesthesiology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Anatomical Pathology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Haematology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Internal Medicine]] * [[MMed]] in [[Microbiology]] and [[Immunology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Obstetrics and Gynecology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Ophthalmology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Orthopedics]] and [[Physical trauma|Trauma]] * [[MMed]] in [[Otorhinolaryngology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Pediatrics]] * [[MMed]] in [[Psychiatry]] * [[MMed]] in [[Radiology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Surgery]]
==Uganda==
===Gulu University=== The following MMed courses are available at [[Gulu University School of Medicine]]:<ref>[http://gu.ac.ug/postgraduate-diplomas-and-master-degrees MMed Courses at Gulu]</ref>
* [[MMed]] in [[Surgery]] * [[MMed]] in [[Psychiatry]]
===Makerere University=== The following MMed courses are available at [[Makerere University School of Medicine]]:<ref>[http://www.med.mak.ac.ug MMed Courses at Makerere] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090505031227/http://med.mak.ac.ug/ |date=2009-05-05 }}</ref>
* [[MMed]] in [[Anesthesiology|Anesthesiology and Critical Care]] * [[MMed]] in [[Family Medicine]] * [[MMed]] in [[Internal Medicine]] * [[MMed]] in [[Oncology|Medical Oncology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Neurosurgery]] * [[MMed]] in [[Obstetrics and Gynecology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Ophthalmology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Otolaryngology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Pediatrics]] * [[MMed]] in [[Psychiatry]] * [[MMed]] in [[Surgery]] * [[MMed]] in [[Surgical Oncology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Urology]]
===Mbarara University=== The following MMed courses are available at [[Mbarara University School of Medicine]]:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://med.must.ac.ug/academic-programmes/postgraduate|title=Postgraduate|author=|date=|website=must.ac.ug|accessdate=7 April 2018}}</ref>
* [[MMed]] in [[Internal Medicine]] * [[MMed]] in [[Obstetrics and Gynecology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Pediatrics]] * [[MMed]] in [[Surgery]] * [[MMed]] in [[Surgery|Plastic & Reconstructive Surgery]]
===Uganda Martyrs University=== The following MMed courses are available at [[Uganda Martyrs University School of Medicine]]:<ref>{{cite web| first=Al Mahdi|accessdate=13 December 2015|title=Nkozi Links Up With Nsambya Hospital|last=Ssenkabirwa| url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/Education/-/688336/892812/-/format/xhtml/-/ajq7ua/-/index.html|newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]]|date=5 April 2010| location=Kampala}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|accessdate=13 December 2015| url=http://www.umu.ac.ug/sites/default/files/application-form-nsambya_0_0.pdf|format=PDF||title=Uganda Martyrs University - Mother Kevin Postgraduate Medical School Nsambya: Application Form for the Master of Medicine Course|date=February 2015|first=|last=UMU|location=Kampala| publisher=[[Uganda Martyrs University]] (UMU)}}</ref>
* [[MMed]] in [[Internal Medicine]] * [[MMed]] in [[Obstetrics and Gynecology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Pediatrics]] * [[MMed]] in [[Surgery]] * [[MMed]] in [[Emergency Medicine]]
==Zambia==
===copperbelt university=== The following MMed courses are available at [[copperbelt university]]:<ref>[http://www.cbu.ac.zm/sm/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=165&Itemid=202 MMed Courses Available At CBU School of Medicine]</ref>
* [[MMed]] in [[Pediatrics]] * [[MMed]] in [[Clinical Pathology]] * [[MMed]] in [[Psychiatry]] * [[MMed]] in [[Internal Medicine]] * [[MMed]] in [[Infectious Diseases]] *MMed in General Surgery *MMed in Urology *MMed in Orthopaedics and Trauma *MMed in Obstetrics and Gynecology *MMed in Family Medicine *MMed in Ophthalmology *MMed in Ortorhinolaryngology *MMed in Anaesthesiology and Intensive Care
==Zimbabwe==
===University of Zimbabwe=== The following MMed courses are available at [[University of Zimbabwe]]:
* [[MMed]] in [[Medicine]] * [[MMed]] in [[Anaesthetics]] * [[MMed]] in [[Obstetrics]] * [[MMed]] in [[Paediatrics]] * [[MMed]] in [[Surgery]]

revision.text:
In [[human geography]], '''McNeill's law''' is the process outlined in [[William Hardy McNeill|William H. McNeill's]] book ''Plagues and Peoples''. The process described concerns the role of [[pathogens|microbial disease]] in the conquering of people-groups.<ref>{{cite book |title=Plagues and People |last= McNeill |first=William |isbn=978-1439503133 |page=340}}</ref>
According to McNeill's Law, the microbiological aspect of conquest and invasion has been the deciding principle or one of the deciding principles in both the expansion of certain [[empire]]s (as during the emigration to the Americas) and the containment in others (as during the [[crusades]]).<ref>{{cite magazine | url=http://magazine.uchicago.edu/1008/features/a-germ-of-an-idea.shtml | title=A germ of an idea | publisher=[[University of Chicago]] Alumni Association | work=University of Chicago Magazine | date=July–August 2010 | accessdate=May 3, 2016 | author=Goodier, Robert | issn=0041-9508}}</ref>
==Instances in history== The first people-group fully [[genocide|wiped out]] due to [[Age of Exploration|European expansion]] (with the possible exception of the [[Arawaks]]) was the [[Guanches]] of the [[Canary Islands]]. Despite an inbred ferocity, superior knowledge of the land and even a possible tactical superiority, they were eventually wiped out through the concentrated efforts of the [[Spain|Spanish]] and [[Portugal|Portuguese]]. McNeill's Law would place the deciding factor squarely on the introduction of deadly diseases and parasites from the mainland to the previously geographically isolated islanders.
This is the likely explanation, as what records still exist show numerous deaths by disease on the islands and a declining birth-rate, leading eventually to the almost complete end of the Guanches as a race.
Other instances include the devastation of the [[Incas]] by [[smallpox]].
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Mcneill's Law}} [[Category:Human geography]] [[Category:Epidemiology]]
{{Hist-stub}}

{{Chembox | Verifiedfields = changed | Watchedfields = changed | verifiedrevid = 401608822 | Name = 3-Methylcholanthrene | ImageFile1 = 3-Me-cholanthrene chemical structure.svg | ImageFile2 = Methylcholanthrene.png | IUPACName = 3-methyl-1,2-dihydrobenzo[j]aceanthrylene | OtherNames = 20–Methylcholanthrene |Section1={{Chembox Identifiers | Abbreviations = 3-MC
20-MC | ChemSpiderID_Ref = {{chemspidercite|correct|chemspider}} | ChemSpiderID = 1611 | ChEBI_Ref = {{ebicite|correct|EBI}} | ChEBI = 34342 | ChEMBL_Ref = {{ebicite|correct|EBI}} | ChEMBL = 40583 | StdInChI_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChI = 1S/C21H16/c1-13-6-7-15-12-20-17-5-3-2-4-14(17)8-9-18(20)19-11-10-16(13)21(15)19/h2-9,12H,10-11H2,1H3 | StdInChIKey_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChIKey = PPQNQXQZIWHJRB-UHFFFAOYSA-N | CASNo_Ref = {{cascite|correct|CAS}} | CASNo = 56-49-5 | PubChem = 1674 | SMILES = CC1=C2CCC3=C2C(=CC4=C3C=CC5=CC=CC=C54)C=C1 }} |Section2={{Chembox Properties | Formula = C21H16 | MolarMass = 268.35174 g/mol | Appearance = Pale yellow solid | Density = 1.28 g/cu cm at 20 °C | MeltingPtC = 180 | BoilingPtC = 280 | Solubility = not, but in xylene, toluene and benzene | MagSus = -194·10−6 cm3/mol }} |Section3={{Chembox Hazards | MainHazards = | FlashPt = | AutoignitionPt = }} }} '''Methylcholanthrene''' is a highly [[carcinogen]]ic [[polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon]] produced by burning [[organic compound]]s at very high temperatures{{Clarify|date=February 2009| title = 3-methylcholanthrene}}. Methylcholanthrene is also known as 3-methylcholanthrene, 20-methylcholanthrene or the IUPAC name 3-methyl-1,2-dyhydrobenzo[j]aceanthrylene. The short notation often used is '''3-MC''' or '''MCA'''. This compound forms pale yellow solid crystals when crystallized from benzene and ether.{{cite web| URL = https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/3-methylcholanthrene#section=Top| title = 3-methylcholanthrene}} It has a melting point around 180 °C and its boiling point is around 280 °C at a pressure of 80 mmHg.{{cite news| author = Lide, D. R.| title = CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics 88th Edition| year = 2007| page = 173}} Methylcholanthrene is used in laboratory studies of chemical carcinogenesis. It is an alkylated derivative of [[benz(a)anthracene|benz[''a'']anthracene]] and has a similar UV spectrum. The most common isomer is 3-methylcholanthrene, although the [[methyl group]] can occur in other places. 3-Methylcholanthrene, a known carcinogen which builds up in the prostate due to [[cholesterol]] breakdown, is implicated in [[prostate cancer]].{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}} It "readily produces" primary [[sarcomas]] in mice.{{cite journal | title = Development of a Cancer DNA Phenotype Prior to Tumor Formation |author1=Donald C. Malins |author2=Katie M. Anderson |author3=Naomi K. Gilman |author4=Virginia M. Green |author5=Edward A. Barker |author6=Karl Erik Hellström | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America | year = 2004 | volume = 101 | issue = 29 | pages = 10721–10725 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0403888101 | pmid = 15249662 | pmc = 490001 | jstor=3372726}} == History == In 1933, the first article about methylcholanthrene was published. Here they described the synthesis of the compound. Not many years later, it became clear that this compound had toxic properties to humans and animals. Therefore, a lot of interest was shown in the compound and it was used often in [[toxicology|toxicological]] research. Methylcholanthrene is often tested on mice and rats to derive information for cancer medicine development. Due to the influence of the compound on the [[central nervous system]], its responses and change in response are compared. It is also known that due to genetic mutations, the compound causes cancer cells to develop.{{cite journal |last1=Duran-Reynals |first1=M. L. |last2=Stanley |first2=B. |date=1961-12-15 |title=Vaccinia dermal infection and methylcholanthrene in cortisone-treated mice |journal=Science |volume=134 |issue=3494 |pages=1984–1985 |doi=10.1126/science.134.3494.1984 |pmid=13888610}} In 1982, the last article appeared on the synthesis of methylcholanthrene. The yield of 93% was reached and therefore no further adjustments were made to the synthesis scheme. == Synthesis == :[[File:Synthesis of methylcholanthrene.png|thumb|left|1. Synthesis of methylcholanthrene]] First 3-MC was synthesized with the method of reference.{{cite news|author1=J.W. Cook |author2=G.A.D. Haslewood |lastauthoramp=yes | title = The synthesis of 5 : 6-dimethyl-1 : 2-benzanthraquinone, a degradation product of deoxycholic acid|journal = Journal of the Chemical Society| year = 1934| page = 428}} Later the synthesis of the compound was improved.{{cite news|author1=Jacobs, S. A. |author2=Harvey, R. G. | title = Synthesis of 3-methylcholanthrene| journal = Tetrahedron Letters| year = 1981| volume = 22| pages = 1093–1096}}{{cite news|author1=Harvey, R. G. |author2=Cortez, C. |author3=Jacobs, S. A. | title = Synthesis of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons via a novel annelation method| journal = The Journal of Organic Chemistry| year = 1982| volume = 47 |issue=11 | pages = 2120–2125}} The synthesis of 3-MC consists of a few steps, visualized in figure 1; the first step is the key to success for the synthesis. 4-methylindanone (1) reacts in condensation with lithium salt of N,N-diethyl-1-naphthamide (2). At -60 ̊C the reaction of 1 and 2 afforded evenly to the lactone (3), the carbonyl addition product which underwent conversion on treatment with acid. The free acid (4) was obtained when the latter was cleaved reductively with zinc and alkali. Cyclization of the product occurred when treated with ZnCl2 in acetic acid anhydride and gave the compound 6-acetoxy-3-MC (5). Reducing this product with hydriodic acid in propionic acid resulted in 3-MC. == Mechanism == [[File:Methylchloranthrene mechanism.JPG|thumb|left|2.Methylcholanthrene mechanism]] 3-MC has an inhibitory function in a [[dimethylnitrosamine]] [[demethylase]] process in rat livers. Inhibition could happen on by interfering in demethylase conformations or by interfering in synthesis and/or degradation of demethylase. Experiments showed that the Km doesn’t change after 3-MC treatment. This strongly indicates that enzyme affinity is not influenced by 3-MC. Instead, incubation with 3-MC leads to a decrease in the amount of [[enzyme activity]]. These results point towards inhibition of demethylase synthesis and/or induction of demetylase degradation. Unpublished observations of Venkatesan, Argus and Arcos suggest that demethylase synthesis inhibition is most plausible.{{cite journal |title=Mechanism of 3-methylcholanthrene-induced inhibition of dimethylnitrosamine demethylase in rat liver |last1=Venkatesan |first1=Natarajan |last2=Argus |first2=Mary F. |last3=Arcos |first3=Joseph C. |year=1970 |journal=Cancer Research |volume=30 |issue=10 |pages=2556–2562 |pmid=5474178 |url=http://cancerres.aacrjournals.org/content/30/10/2556.long}} A possible mechanism for this reaction is depicted in figure (2). 3-MC is metabolized, via [[epoxidation]], [[hydrolysis]] and another epoxidation, to a very reactive epoxide. Epoxidations are realized by the enzyme [[cytochrome P450]]. The second epoxide is not hydrolysed immediately because it is localized next to a bay region, which shields the epoxide. This way, the metabolite is able to travel and bind to DNA in figure (2). The mechanism is derived from the binding mechanism of [[Benzo(a)pyrene|benzo[''a'']pyrene]] to DNA. This is likely because it is plausible that two [[polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon]]s are metabolized via the same pathway. [[Deoxyguanosine]] is used in the figure, since that base appears to be bound to Benzo[a]pyrene far more often than the other bases.{{cite journal |last1=Eastman |first1=Alan |last2=Sweetenham |first2=John |last3=Bresnick |first3=Edward |title=Comparison of in vivo and in vitro binding of polycyclic hydrocarbons to DNA |date=1978 |journal=Chemico-Biological Interactions |volume=23 |issue=3 |pages=345–353 |doi=10.1016/0009-2797(78)90095-9 |pmid=719814}} There appears to be an equilibrium in 3-MC-free and 3-MC-bound. It is hard to determine how when the equilibrium is formed due to difficulties with radioactive measurements. A probable saturating dosis is thought to be around 40 mg 3-MC/kg.{{cite journal |last1=Lasnitzki |first1=I. |last2=Bard |first2=D. R. |last3=Franklin |first3=H. R. |date=1975 |title=3-Methylcholanthrene uptake and metabolism in organ culture |journal=British Journal of Cancer |volume=32 |issue=2 |pages=219–229 |doi=10.1038/bjc.1975.152 |pmc=2024855 |pmid=1240005}} Research on the effect of 3-MC in rat uteri concludes that 3-MC acts as an estrogen antagonist. The sexhormone is, like 3-MC, a polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon. 3-MC and estrogen bind to estrogenreceptors competitively, reducing the estrogen expression.{{cite journal |last1=Sheen |first1=Y. Y. |last2=Kim |first2=S. S. |last3=Yun |first3=H. C. |title=Effect of 3-methylcholanthrene on rat uterus: Uterine growth and mechanism of action of 3-methylcholanthrene |journal=Archives of Pharmacal Research |page=276 |volume=16 |doi=10.1007/bf02977516}} ==Metabolism== MC is metabolized by rat liver microsomes into oxygenated forms which alkylate DNA. These oxygenated metabolites bind to double-stranded and single-stranded. Empirical data show that MC tends to bind mostly to G-bases8.{{cite journal |last1=Dauben |first1=William G. |last2=Mabee |first2=Dorothea |title=A Study of the Metabolism of 20-Methylcholanthrene |date=1951 |journal=Cancer Research |volume=11 |issue=3 |pages=216–220 |pmid=14821965 |url=http://cancerres.aacrjournals.org/content/11/3/216.long}} When injected in lung, kidney or liver tissue of rats, it appears that the liver is able to reverse the MC-binding to DNA. Lung and kidney tissue are not capable of doing this, which may explain why MC is more carcinogenic in lungs and kidneys than in the liver. To be carcinogenic, the MC metabolite has to be covalently bound to DNA. Therefor it’s necessary for MC to be oxygenated in order to carcinogenic. Injected MC does not move away from the injection site. In a rat body MC has a half-life of about 4 weeks. After 8 weeks, 80% of MC is metabolized into water-soluble metabolites. MC and it’s metabolites mainly exit the body via feces (a ninefold more urine). Three months after injection with MC, 85% of the rats are reported to have tumors. 82% of the tumors is a form of spindle-cell sarcoma. ==Efficacy== Methylcholanthrene is often used to induce tumors in rodents for carcinogenesis and mutagenesis research. In a study from 1991, lung precancerous and cancerous lesions were induced in Wistar rats by one intrabronchial injection of 3-MC. After 30 days, atypical hyperplasia of bronchiolar epithelium, adenoid hyperplasia or adenomas, and squamous cell carcinoma occurred in 15 (88.2%), 12 (70.6%) and 3 (17.7%) out of 17 rats respectively. After 60 days, the incidences were 15/18 (83.3%), 4/17 (23.5%) and 7/18 (38.9%). All of the precancerous lesions and carcinomas showed positive expression of gamma-glutamyltranspeptidase (GGT).{{cite journal |author=He, R. |title=Precancerous and cancerous lesions and their gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase expression in 3-methylcholanthrene-induced lung carcinogenesis in rats |journal=Zhongguo Yi Xue Ke Xue Yuan Xue Bao |year=1991 |volume=13 |page=343}} Jin et al. (2013) found that the cellular redox balance is altered by acute exposure to 3-MC. This causes the nuclear factor erythroid 2-related factor 2 (Nrf2)-regulated response pathway to induce antioxidant responses.{{cite journal |author1=Jin Y. |author2=M. W. |author3=Lin X. |author4=Pan X. |author5=Ye Y. |author6=Xu M |author7=Fu Z. |title=Acute exposure to 3-methylcholanthrene induces hepatic oxidative stress via activation of the Nrf2/ARE signaling pathway in mice |journal=Environmental Toxicology |volume=29 |year=2013 |page=1399 |doi=10.1002/tox.21870}} ==Toxicity== 3-MC is a ligand of the aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AhR), which stimulates transcription directed by xenobiotic response elements. AhR ligands can induce formation of an AhR-estrogen receptor (ER) complex. 3-MC was found to elicit estrogenic activity by this mechanism, and by stimulation of the expression of some endogenous ER target genes.{{cite journal |last1=Shipley |first1=J. M. |last2=Waxman |first2=D.J. |title=Aryl hydrocarbon receptor-independent activation of estrogen receptor-dependent transcription by 3-methylcholanthrene |journal=Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology |year=2006 |volume=213 |page=87 |doi=10.1016/j.taap.2005.09.011}} 3-MC may cause respiratory tract irritation, skin irritation or eye irritation.{{cite web |url=http://toxnet.nlm.nih.gov/cgi-bin/sis/search2/f?./temp/~UiCKMb:1 |title=TOXNET |publisher=U.S. National Library of Medicine}} ==Effects on animals== ===Effects on human=== 3-MC is mutagenic to human cells. Curren et al. (1978) were the first to report successfully induced mutations in human cells with 3-MC. Skin epithelial cells are thought to metabolize the compound to mutagenic products.{{cite journal |last1=Curren |first1=R. D. |last2=Homer |first2=C.J. |last3=Price |first3=P.J. |last4=Freeman |first4=A.E. |title=Mutagenesis of human cells by 3-methylcholanthrene |journal=Mutation Research |year=1978 |volume=60 |page=109 |doi=10.1016/0027-5107(79)90214-8}} The ability to metabolize mutagens may express genetically regulated differences within a species such as man or mouse, causing environmental chemicals to show a different level of mutagenicity and carcinogenicity to specific individuals.{{cite journal |last1=Hutton |first1=J. J. |last2=Meier |first2=J. |last3=Hackney |first3=C. |title=Comparison of the in vitro mutagenicity and metabolism of dimethylnitrosamine and benzo[a]pyrene in tissues from inbred mice treated with phenobarbital, 3-methylcholanthrene or polychlorinated biphenyls |journal=Mutation Research |year=1978 |volume=60 |page=90 |doi=10.1016/0165-1218(79)90010-7}} ===Non-human toxicity studies=== The administration of 3-MC to pregnant mice results in the formation of lung tumors in the offspring. Miller et al. (1990) compared the effects of fetal versus adult exposure to 3-MC on both induction of aryl hydrocarbon hydroxylase (AHH) activity in lung and dependence of lung tumorigenesis on the Ah genotype. A single ip injection (in inducible fetal lung supernatants) of 100 mg/kg of 3-MC to the mothers resulted in a maximal 50-fold induction of AHH activity by 8 hr, which persisted for 48 hr. The same injections to adult F1 mice revealed only a 4- to 7—fold increase in lung AHH activity, compared to the large fetal induction ratio.{{cite journal |last1=Miller |first1=M. S. |last2=Jones |first2=A.B. |last3=Park |first3=S.S. |last4=Anderson |first4=L.M. |title=The formation of 3-methylcholanthrene-initiated lung tumors correlates with induction of cytochrome P450IA1 by the carcinogen in fetal but not in adult mice |journal=Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology |year=1990 |volume=104 |page=235 |doi=10.1016/0041-008x(90)90298-9}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060518002254/http://www.npi.gov.au/database/substance-info/profiles/74.html National Pollutant Inventory - Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbon Fact Sheet] {{Nuclear receptor modulators}} [[Category:Carcinogens]] [[Category:Hepatotoxins]] [[Category:Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons]]
